Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Story:
I was halfway through tightening a bolt on the scaffolding when my phone buzzed in my pocket—a reminder for the weekly team meeting with my office colleagues. I was supposed to log in, share updates, and show I was engaged, even though the meeting would be recorded. At the same moment, the piercing site alarm blared, echoing across the construction yard. Instinctively, I knew what that meant: drop everything, leave my tools, and head straight to the muster point with the rest of the crew. Site safety protocols were strict, and any delay could put me and others at risk.

But as I reached for my hard hat, I hesitated. My manager at the office had already commented on my lack of participation in meetings, and I worried about seeming unreliable. Yet, if I stayed behind to join the call, I’d be breaking site rules and letting down my team here. My heart pounded as I stood between the scaffolding and the path to the muster point, torn between the expectations of two worlds that didn’t seem to understand each other.
